Name: Pythagoras
Major Contributions: Best known for the Pythagorean theorem, which relates the sides of a right triangle. His contributions also extend to musical theory and philosophical concepts of numbers and their relationships.

Name: Euclid
Major Contributions: Often referred to as the 'Father of Geometry,' Euclid's work 'Elements' is one of the most influential works in the history of mathematics, laying out the foundations of plane geometry.

Name: Nicolaus Copernicus
Major Contributions: Proposed the heliocentric model of the solar system, which placed the Sun, rather than the Earth, at the center. This was a major milestone in the history of astronomy.

Name: Galileo Galilei
Major Contributions: Pioneered the use of the telescope in astronomy, made numerous key observations (such as the moons of Jupiter), and laid the groundwork for classical mechanics.

Name: Marin Mersenne
Major Contributions: Known for Mersenne primes and contributions to the study of acoustics and number theory. Acted as a central figure in the scientific community of his time.

Name: René Descartes
Major Contributions: Developed Cartesian coordinate system, which bridges algebra and Euclidean geometry. Also contributed to philosophy, laying the foundation for modern rationalism.

Name: Isaac Newton
Major Contributions: Formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, laying the groundwork for classical mechanics. Also made substantial contributions to calculus, optics, and mathematical theory.

Name: Johann Bernoulli
Major Contributions: Played a key role in the development of calculus and its applications to mechanics and fluid dynamics. Known for Bernoulli's principle in fluid dynamics.

Name: Leonhard Euler
Major Contributions: Made significant contributions to a wide variety of fields in mathematics, including topology, graph theory, and introducing modern terminologies and notations. Known for Euler's identity and Euler's formula.

Name: Jean le Rond d'Alembert
Major Contributions: Developed the d'Alembert principle in dynamics and made significant contributions to the wave equation in physics. Was also a co-editor of the 'Encyclopédie.'

Name: Alessandro Volta
Major Contributions: Pioneer in electricity and power. Invented the electric battery and discovered methane. The unit of electric potential, the volt, is named in his honor.

Name: Pierre-Simon Laplace
Major Contributions: Known for his work on celestial mechanics, probability, and statistics. Formulated the Laplace transform and made significant contributions to the study of the stability of the solar system.

Name: André-Marie Ampère
Major Contributions: One of the founders of electrodynamics (the study of the interaction of electric currents), known for Ampère's circuital law and the ampere unit of electric current.

Name: Carl Friedrich Gauss
Major Contributions: Made major contributions to many fields including number theory, algebra, statistics, analysis, differential geometry, geophysics, electrostatics, astronomy, and optics. Known for the Gaussian distribution and the fundamental theorem of algebra.

Name: Joseph Fourier
Major Contributions: Introduced the Fourier series and Fourier transform, which are widely used in signal processing, heat transfer, and vibrations. His work laid the foundation for modern harmonic analysis.

Name: Sophie Germain
Major Contributions: Made important contributions to number theory and elasticity theory. Her work on Fermat's Last Theorem provided a foundation for later proofs.

Name: Siméon Denis Poisson
Major Contributions: Known for Poisson distribution in probability theory and Poisson's equation in potential theory. Made significant contributions to the study of heat conduction.

Name: Augustin-Louis Cauchy
Major Contributions: One of the founders of complex analysis and the theory of functions. Known for Cauchy-Riemann equations and contributions to the rigor of calculus.

Name: Michael Faraday
Major Contributions: Discovered electromagnetic induction, diamagnetism, and electrolysis. Faraday's law of induction is fundamental in the study of electromagnetism.

Name: William Rowan Hamilton
Major Contributions: Made important contributions to classical mechanics, optics, and algebra. Known for Hamiltonian mechanics, which reformulates Newtonian mechanics.

Name: Évariste Galois
Major Contributions: Developed Galois theory, which provides a connection between field theory and group theory. His work laid the foundation for much of modern algebra.

Name: James Clerk Maxwell
Major Contributions: Formulated the classical theory of electromagnetic radiation, bringing together for the first time electricity, magnetism, and light as manifestations of the same phenomenon. Known for Maxwell's equations.

Name: Jules Henri Poincaré
Major Contributions: Considered the last universalist in mathematics, made profound contributions to the fields of topology, celestial mechanics, and the theory of dynamical systems. Known for the Poincaré conjecture.

Name: Felix Klein
Major Contributions: Known for his work in group theory, complex analysis, non-Euclidean geometry, and the Erlangen program, which classified geometries based on their underlying symmetries.

Name: Georg Cantor
Major Contributions: Founded set theory and introduced the concept of cardinality of infinite sets. His work laid the foundations for much of modern mathematical logic.

Name: Henri Poincaré
Major Contributions: Made fundamental contributions to topology, celestial mechanics, and the theory of dynamical systems. Known for the Poincaré conjecture and his work on the three-body problem.

Name: Max Planck
Major Contributions: Originated quantum theory, which revolutionized human understanding of atomic and subatomic processes. Known for Planck's constant and black-body radiation.

Name: Henri Lebesgue
Major Contributions: Developed the theory of measure and integration, known as Lebesgue integration, which extended the notion of integration to a broader class of functions.

Name: Émile Borel
Major Contributions: Made fundamental contributions to measure theory and probability theory. Known for Borel sets and Borel measure, which are foundational in modern analysis.

Name: David Hilbert
Major Contributions: Contributed to a broad range of fields, including invariant theory, algebraic number theory, and the foundations of geometry. Known for Hilbert spaces in functional analysis.

Name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
Major Contributions: Made substantial contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions. His work has inspired a vast amount of research.

Name: Erwin Schrödinger
Major Contributions: Developed wave mechanics and formulated the Schrödinger equation, which describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes over time.

Name: Niels Bohr
Major Contributions: Developed the Bohr model of the atom, which introduced quantum theory to atomic structure. Made foundational contributions to understanding atomic and molecular structure.

Name: Albert Einstein
Major Contributions: Developed the theory of relativity, fundamentally changing our understanding of space, time, and energy. Known for the equation E=mc^2 and his contributions to the photoelectric effect.

Name: Emmy Noether
Major Contributions: Made groundbreaking contributions to abstract algebra and theoretical physics. Known for Noether's theorem, which links symmetries and conservation laws in physics.

Name: Paul Dirac
Major Contributions: One of the pioneers of quantum mechanics and quantum electrodynamics. Known for the Dirac equation, which describes the behavior of fermions and predicted the existence of antimatter.

Name: Werner Heisenberg
Major Contributions: Developed matrix mechanics, one of the formulations of quantum mechanics. Known for the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, which states a fundamental limit to the precision with which pairs of physical properties can be known.

Name: Kurt Gödel
Major Contributions: Best known for his incompleteness theorems, which have profound implications for the limits of formal systems in mathematics and logic.

Name: John von Neumann
Major Contributions: Made fundamental contributions to many fields, including set theory, functional analysis, quantum mechanics, and computer science. Known for the von Neumann architecture and game theory.

Name: Andrey Kolmogorov
Major Contributions: Made significant contributions to probability theory, turbulence, and the theory of computation. Known for the Kolmogorov axioms, which are the foundation of modern probability theory.

Name: Richard Feynman
Major Contributions: Developed the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics and contributed to the theory of quantum electrodynamics. Known for Feynman diagrams, which are used to represent particle interactions.

Name: Paul Erdős
Major Contributions: Prolific mathematician who contributed to numerous fields, particularly combinatorics, graph theory, number theory, and probability. Known for the Erdős number, which measures collaborative distance in authorship of mathematical papers.

Name: Alan Turing
Major Contributions: Considered the father of computer science. Developed the concept of the Turing machine, which is a fundamental model of computation, and played a crucial role in codebreaking during World War II.

Name: John Nash
Major Contributions: Made fundamental contributions to game theory, differential geometry, and the study of partial differential equations. Known for Nash equilibrium in game theory.

Name: Stephen Hawking
Major Contributions: Made significant contributions to the fields of cosmology and quantum gravity, particularly in the context of black holes. Known for Hawking radiation.
